Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal- Planning for the Future: Developing a Five Year Plan for Wildsumaco Biological Station
Award.AbstractNarration:
Wildsumaco Biological Station's (WBS) primary mission is scientific research and education (www.wildsumacobio.org). WBS itself is a collaboration between Francis Marion University (FMU), the University of North Carolina Wilmington, Pontificia Universidad Cat√≥lica del Ecuador and Wildsumaco Wildlife Sanctuary (WWS). Although the station only opened in 2012, it is quickly becoming a hub for high quality teaching and research in the Sumaco region. WBS has hosted numerous undergraduate courses and produced a number of scientific papers and presentations. This grant allows for the development of a comprehensive five year plan to facilitate WBS's development into a world class ecological research station, with a number of societal benefits. First, because WBS is located in one of the world's premier biodiversity hotspots, improving research at the station will increase our understanding of tropical biodiversity. In particular, developing partnerships with other field stations along the east slope of the Andes will allow for coordinated monitoring of biodiversity changes from lowland tropical rainforest to high elevation cloud forests. Second, developing the station will enhance educational opportunities for underrepresented groups. Most students at FMU come from poor, rural areas of South Carolina, with a very high proportion of minority students. The opportunity to conduct ecological research in one of the world's biodiversity hotspots is a unique opportunity for many of these underrepresented groups, and one that not only engages them in science, but also global culture. Third, the enhanced research and education occurring at the station will have practical management consequences. The research being done at the Wildsumaco Wildlife Sanctuary and within Sumaco National Park itself are helping to better educate park staff on local biodiversity, as well as inform management decisions and improve the potential to develop ecotourism as a viable alternative to the destructive timber practices that threaten the surrounding forest.

Key partners in this activity include the University of North Carolina Wilmington and the Pontifical Catholic University of Ecuador. WBS's location in the Tropical Andes biodiversity hotspot, at the confluence of lowland Amazonian and highland Andean biotas, render it a site of global ecological and conservation significance. In addition to high potential for new species discovery, WBS is an ideal site in which to monitor distributional changes of species driven by global climate change and associated shifting climate envelopes in this megadiverse region. This planning process will produce a five year action plan for management of the station, identify infrastructure needs for current and future students and researchers, and establish and enhance scientific collaboration and educational outreach. This will be accomplished in part through three planning workshops. The first, in the USA, will seek advice and strategies from invited staff of established field stations. The second, in Ecuador, will seek input and solidify commitments from WBS managers, stakeholders, and the local community, and will include visits to three similar research stations to learn from their experience. The third and final workshop in the USA will distill and collate information from the previous workshops, and seek guidance from scientists and business faculty to draft the final five year plan of action. The plan will identify the most efficient strategy to maintain and enhance WBS's scientific and educational programs, the dissemination of research findings to the scientific community and general public, and recruitment of research groups and students (particularly minority students) to the station. The WBS website is located at http://www.wildsumacobio.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To date we have held two of our three planned workshops. The first, held in December 2015 at Francis Marion University, involved biological station directors from the University of Cincinnati, Pomona College (CA), the University of Georgia (Costa Rica), Stanford University, and Highlands Biological Station (NC). Also in attendance were all four grant PIs.  The second workshop was held in May 2016, on site at Wildsumaco Biological Station in Ecuador. In attendance were three of the USA station directors from the December 2015 workshop, as well as the four grant PIs, five faculty and researchers from the Pontifical Catholic University of Ecuador (or primary in-country collaborators), two additional faculty from Francis Marion University, and representatives of the local property owners and management company, Wildsumaco Wildlife Sanctuary.

The objectives of the first workshop were to obtain an overview of other field station operations in the US and abroad, including staffing and station management, budgetary considerations, data management, and perceived needs for onsite equipment and services that facilitate use by visiting students and researchers. Another goal was identifying fundraising opportunities for sustaining WBS’s current mission, and growth opportunities for the future. The objectives of the second workshop included the following: Visit other stations and field sites in Ecuador to observe their unique achievements and challenges, and explore research coordination among their facilities and WBS; acquire input from in-country constituencies about increasing scientific partnerships at WBS and increasing its use by their own researchers and students; and identify the infrastructure and service needs of WBS.

Prior to holding the workshops, the PIs surveyed station directors throughout the USA and at appropriate international biological stations abroad, as identified through the membership database of the Organization of Biological Field Stations. A Survey Monkey instrument was used to obtain preliminary information about station operations, which assisted us with selecting workshop participants.

Several key recommendations have already emerged from the first two workshops. Those from the first include the need to increase collaboration and involvement with local students and citizens around WBS; insuring a cost-efficient but reliable infrastructure to support research and education; a dedicated and reliable data management system, including geospatial data and GIS subscriptions, for sharing research findings with other scientists and the public; development of a master plan of the station’s physical layout to insure smart planning of future growth, and buy-in by collaborating institutions; and acquisition of Internet service for the station. Workshop participants also suggested the importance of generating more publicity and outreach efforts for WBS through photography and videos of wildlife, and student and faculty research; published (print and electronic) findings and species lists; and maintaining an active social media presence. Workshop participants also advised the PIs on elements of successful grant proposals, and the importance of establishing a Board of Directors and station bylaws.

The second workshop, held at WBS, produced many additional recommendations. These include the need to increase station occupancy to provide a sounder footing to the operational budget. Key infrastructure needs include Internet connectivity for the station, and a number of potential providers and solutions were identified. Potential research collaborations for WBS were identified, including EVOTRAC and the Carnegie Airborne Observatory (CAO). The need for data management, ownership, transmission to the public, and data backup were reemphasized.

Possibilities for faculty and student exchange between the US institutional partners and the Pontifical Catholic Universitiy of Ecuador were discussed, as were mechanisms for increasing the attractiveness of WBS to other Ecuadorian institutions. Programs at WBS may be interdisciplinary, and not necessarily restricted to biological research.

Also discussed were the importance of local community outreach, which is mandatory in Ecuador. Workshop participants toured local ecotourism and sustainable agriculture initiatives, and explored WBS involvement in assisting and collaborating with these ventures.

Primary infrastructure needs include a new dedicated laboratory and classroom building, to separate these functions from the existing “common use” building, which also doubles as a dining hall. The importance of demonstrating the facility’s relevance to existing NSF funded projects is key. Another goal in medium- to long-term planning is some additional housing options, especially for graduate students or researchers who might need longer terms in residence to collect data. Additional fundraising strategies involving granting agencies, foundations, tourism, and private donors were also discussed.

Finally, a key recommendation that emerged more than once was the need for a dedicated, full-time manager for WBS, separate from staff dedicated to the Wildlife Sanctuary.

The third and final workshop will be held at Francis Marion University in Spring or Summer of 2017 (under a no-cost extension granted to the FMU PIs under award 1522209). A separate final report, including information from the third workshop, will be submitted under award 1522209,
